I. THE PROPOSAL
1. I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of
up to $40,000,000 (or its yuan equivalent) to CD Finance Management Co., Ltd. (CFM) for the
CD Finance Management Expanding Access to Finance for Farmers and Microentrepreneurs
Project in the People’s Republic of China (PRC).
2. The project entails the Asian Development Bank (ADB) providing longer-tenor financing
to CFM to support the company’s lending operations to farmers and microentrepreneurs in the
PRC’s rural counties.1 The loan will help expand the availability of microcredit to the underserved,
including women, and support rural economic development.
II. THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY
A. Investment Identification and Description
3. Rural microfinance sector overview. Rapid economic growth in the PRC has lifted more
than 800 million people out of extreme poverty since 1980. In 2015, the government set ambitious
targets for the eradication of extreme poverty and economic development of all poverty-stricken
counties by 2020. The PRC has since made steady progress toward achieving these targets. The
number of people living in extreme poverty, based on the PRC’s national poverty line of CNY2,300
(2011 constant price) per person per year, gradually declined from 55.8 million in 2015 to 30.5
million in 2017 and to 5.5 million in 2019. The number of poverty-stricken counties declined from
832 in 2015 to 679 in 2017 and to 52 in 2019. However, the fight against poverty is far from over
and the impact of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) might reverse some of the gains. Extreme
poverty remains and income disparity between urban and rural areas persists, with most of the
low-income population living in rural areas. The per capita disposable income in 2019 was
CNY16,021 for rural households, while that for urban households was more than 2.6 times higher.
Women account for more than 60% of the rural labor force and perform most of the agricultural
work.2 However, they are often marginalized because they have less opportunities for education
than men and lack access to skills and information.3
4. The rural market has large unmet financial needs. As of year-end 2018, 560 million people
lived in rural areas, including 210 million small farmers.4 The financing gap is estimated to be
more than CNY3 trillion.5 Accelerating rural financial innovation to improve access to finance,
particularly for women, and bridging the gaps in rural financial services are key to achieving
sustainable rural development. However, rural financial markets are generally perceived as higher
risk than traditional banking markets with higher costs and lower returns. The unavailability of
acceptable or traditional collateral for borrowing hinders rural households’ access to credit, as
assets held in rural areas are less valuable and marketable in case of loan defaults. Agricultural
income is low and volatile. The general lack of acceptable collateral combined with a low level of
disposable income makes providing rural credit services unattractive.
1  A county is a local administrative division covering the rural areas of a prefecture city. 
2 Permanent Mission of the People’s Republic of China to the UN Office at Geneva and other International 
Organizations in Switzerland. Gender Equality and Women's Development in China. 
3  ADB. 2016. Country Partnership Strategy: Transforming Partnership: People’s Republic of China and Asian

4  Those whose farms are smaller than 10 mu (1 mu = 666.67 square meters).  
5  Chinese Academy of Social Science. 2016. China Rural Internet Finance Development Report. Beijing.

2 
5. In 2005, the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) permitted the establishment of microcredit
companies (MCCs) to promote the development of inclusive finance, but with tight restrictions to 
minimize any negative impacts on financial stability. As of March 2020, the PRC had 7,458 MCCs, 
with total registered capital of CNY816.98 billion and total outstanding loans of CNY806.3 billion.6 
However, the MCC sector remains fragmented and underdeveloped and few MCCs perform well 
financially.  With  an  average  estimated  loan  size  of  CNY400,000–CNY600,000  ($61,444–
$92,166), most MCCs provide little real microcredit. As PBOC’s 2008 national regulation on MCCs
has become outdated, provincial finance management offices issued local policies for MCCs 
registered in their provinces. MCCs generally have location-based regulatory restrictions and an 
exceedingly  low  cap  on  leverage  ratios,  from  50%  to  400%,  depending  on  the  province. 
Commercial banks are not encouraged or incentivized to lend to MCCs because of the perception 
of the higher risk of sub-borrowers, lending practices, and risk management.7 On 20 August 2020, 
the Supreme Court released Guidelines on Laws Applicable to Trials of Private Lending Cases, 
which cap the legally permissible interest rate for lending by nonregulated financial institutions to 
15.4% (four times the loan prime rate) and could reduce the profitability of the MCC industry if 
strictly applied.8 
6. Impact of COVID-19. The pandemic has had significant impacts on the rural economy.
During the peak of the outbreak in the first quarter of 2020, many farmers suffered losses as they
were unable to deliver their products to market, while rural microbusiness owners incurred losses
because of the government lockdown and weakened demand. The pandemic has reduced urban
jobs, with migrant workers most severely affected because they typically work in industries such
as catering, personal services, retail, and light manufacturing. A National Bureau of Statistics
survey in May 2020 showed that about 10% of the 174 million migrant workers as of year-end
2019 failed to return to work in cities in more developed regions because of the outbreak. The
Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs estimated that more than 8 million migrant workers had
started working in their home counties by the end of May. ADB must, therefore, continue to
support financial institutions that provide access to critically needed finance to start productive
rural activities and maintain livelihoods and existing small businesses.
7. Rationale. ADB’s nonsovereign operations in the PRC’s finance sector have focused on
underserved customer segments and regions, primarily through nonbank financial institutions. In
2016, ADB provided a loan of $50 million to CFM (previously known as CFPA Microfinance
Management) to support microfinance in poverty-stricken counties.9 ADB was the company’s first
international lender outside of its shareholders. The long-term ADB loan supported CFM’s rapid
growth and helped the company attract follow-on funding from commercial impact investors. In
2018, ADB provided $20 million in debt to Microcred Nanchong and Microcred Sichuan to finance
micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises in the western region.10 To continue to maintain and
expand access to finance in rural regions, CFM, the largest microfinance institution in the PRC,
with more than 20 years of operating history and a good track record with ADB, has been identified
as  a  suitable  candidate.  CFM  operates  exclusively  in  rural  counties,  most  of  which  are

underdeveloped, including many officially designated poverty-stricken counties. CFM has good 
risk  management  capacity  and  is  expected to  recover  from  the  impacts  of  the  COVID-19 
pandemic,  which  include  higher  nonperforming  loans.  However,  the  company  will  need  to 
continuously source funding from international partners. 
B. Business Overview and Strategy
8. CFM  was  established  in  2008  as  a  commercially  operated  entity  to  scale  up  the
microfinance activities of the China Foundation for Poverty Alleviation (CFPA) under a joint
program of the World Bank and the Government of the PRC, which had been in operation since
1996. From 1996 to 2008, the initiative had cumulatively disbursed CNY600 million of microloans
to 150,000 households. CFM has been growing rapidly since its establishment in 2008, supported
by several rounds of capital increases, and has transformed from a donor-funded development
project to a sustainable commercial institution. CFM expects to operate exclusively in rural
counties and continue to serve the financial needs of rural low- and middle-income groups.
9. CFM is the largest microfinance institution in the PRC with an outstanding microfinance
loan portfolio of CNY11.25 billion as of June 2020. It currently serves approximately 400,000
active borrowers. About 45% of its borrowers are women. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION
DELETED.
C. Ownership, Management, and Governance
10. Ownership.  CFM’s  ownership  structure  has  changed  since  ADB’s  first  loan.  The
International Finance Corporation (IFC) exited in August after 10 years of supporting CFM’s
commercial transformation. As of 31 August 2020, CFM’s largest shareholder was API (Hong
Kong) Investment Limited, with a 34.63% indirect ownership stake, which is 100% owned by AFS
of Alibaba Group. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. ADB conducted integrity due
diligence.11 CFM, its shareholders, and board of directors do not appear to constitute a significant
or potentially significant integrity risk, as no unresolved, unsubstantiated, or adverse media or
relevant information is related to them. ADB’s review of CFM does not give ADB cause to believe
it is being used for money laundering or financing of terrorism. Tax integrity due diligence was not 
required. 
11. Management. CFM is led by an experienced management team comprising a president;
a chief financial officer (CFO); a chief operations officer, who is concurrently acting chief risk
officer; and a chief technology officer. The president, Dongwen Liu, joined CFPA in 2002 and was
responsible for the non-governmental organization’s microfinance projects since 2005 before
becoming the general manager of CFM when it was established. The CFO, Zhen Li, joined 
CFPA’s microfinance department as financial controller in 2008, and later became CFM’s CFO. 
Z.Li is a certified public accountant and previously worked at Tianhua Zhongxing Accounting Firm
as audit manager, China Merchant Bank, and China Construction Bank as finance manager. The
chief operations officer, who concurrently serves as the chief risk officer, Dianzuo Chen, joined
CFM  in  2015.  Before  joining  CFM,  D.  Chen  was  vice  president  of  Sinotrust  International
Information & Consulting (Beijing) and executive vice president of Zhongxin Tianjian Technology
Information Service. The chief technology officer, Bo Yu, was appointed by AFS in 2017. B. Yu
joined Alibaba Group in 2009 and held various positions in Alibaba Cloud, Alimama, and AFS’s 
artificial intelligence team before joining CFM. 
11 ADB. 2003. Enhancing the Asian Development Bank's Role in Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of 
Terrorism. Manila.

4 
 
12.  Governance structure. CFM maintains a good corporate governance standard. The 
board of directors comprises six members. Two are nominated by AFS, two by TPG, one by 
Sequoia Capital, and one is an executive director. All board members have extensive experience 
in investment and finance. The board chair is Xinyi Han, nominated by AFS. He joined Alibaba 
Group in 2011 and has served as vice president of AFS since 2014, where he is responsible for 
strategic investment and finance. The board has three committees: audit and risk, nomination and 
remuneration, and strategy. The audit and risk committee is responsible for assessing the key 
risks faced by the company; evaluating the internal control and risk management system; making 
recommendations to the board on risk management, accounting policy, and internal audit; 
providing risk warnings to senior management; and ensuring the timely correction of any issues 
and problems identified from internal audit. The nomination and remuneration committee is 
responsible for setting and implementing the guiding principles of the company’s salary and stock 
distribution  policy;  and  approving  the  compensation  package,  employment  contracts,  and 
separation agreements of all members of the senior management team. The strategy committee 
is responsible for recommending to the board the company’s medium- to long-term strategy. 
 
D.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
13.  ADB will provide a senior secured loan to CFM of up to $40 million (or its yuan equivalent) 
with a tenor of up to 5 years. 
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  Use of proceeds. CFM will use the proceeds of the ADB loan to finance microloans of up 
to CNY200,000 to farmers and microentrepreneurs. At least 60% of the ADB-financed loans will 
be disbursed to women sub-borrowers.12 
 
15.  Legal documentation. The loan to CFM will be governed by a facility agreement, which 
will be based on ADB’s customary terms and conditions for a loan of this nature and amount. 
 
16.  Reporting arrangements. ADB will monitor the project over its life. CFM will provide ADB 
with financial and other reports at predetermined regular intervals and as requested, including 
(i) semiannual  unaudited  financial  statements,  (ii)  annual  audited  financial  statements, 
(iii) semiannual compliance certificates for financial covenants, (iv) annual reports on the sub-loan 
portfolio, and (v) annual reports on the selected development indicators and the safeguard and 
social dimension policy agreed by ADB and the borrower. 
 
17.  Evaluation. ADB will prepare monitoring reports regularly and at least annually. The first 
report will be submitted no later than 12 months after the first disbursement. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
18.  Provide long-term stable finance and support rural development. CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED. ADB’s long-term funding will help reduce CFM’s funding risk, which

was exacerbated by the pandemic. ADB’s loan facility has a longer tenor than the company’s 
microfinance products and, as a result, the ADB loans can be rolled over several times, thereby 
maximizing development impact in rural areas, which greatly need access to finance. 
 
19.  Support gender mainstreaming. The project has a gender-specific microloan target of 
60% for women, expected to directly benefit 30,100 women borrowers. A gender action plan has 
been prepared to support the effective gender mainstreaming classification of the project. Gender 
measures will increase CFM’s focus on bringing financing and other services to women and 
providing them with nonfinancial training and financial education. 
 
D.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
20.  Impacts. The project is aligned with the government’s strategy of developing rural finance 
system to support rural revitalization and supporting reemployment of migrant workers affected 
by the COVID-19 pandemic in home regions by developing rural industries.13 The COVID-19 
pandemic has impacted rural economies through supply disruption, demand shock, and reduced 
urban jobs for migrant workers. Micro credit will help farmers and former migrant workers start 
and maintain agriculture and other business activities in the rural areas, thus mitigating the 
pandemic’s impacts. 
 
21.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: uptake of inclusive financial 
services by farmers and microentrepreneurs improved, particularly among women borrowers. 
ADB’s long-term funding will enable CFM to scale up its business despite the increased risk posed 
by the pandemic and provide urgently needed funding to underserved customers, thereby helping 
reduce poverty and income inequality. 
 
22.  Outputs. The outputs will be (i) CFM’s microfinance lending to rural households and male 
and female microentrepreneurs expanded; and (ii) CFM’s ability to render services to women 
clients enhanced through increased participation of women farmers and microentrepreneurs and 
CFM staff members in financial education, nonfinancial training, and dedicated outreach activities. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
23.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project supports three 
Strategy 2030 operational priorities: (i) tackling remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, 
(ii) accelerating progress in gender equality, and (iii) promoting rural development and food 
security.14 The project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2016–2020 for the 
PRC,15 and ADB’s country operations business plan, 2019–2021 for the PRC, which prioritize 
promoting inclusive economic growth, reducing poverty and inequality, developing small and

24.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project is aligned 
with ADB’s Financial Sector Operational Plan, which notes that ADB will support broad-based 
household access to microfinance.18 It supports the operation priorities in the finance sector 
identified  by  ADB’s  Operational  Plan  for  Private  Sector  Operations.19 ADB’s  microfinance 
development strategy calls for tapping the increasing potential of the poor by expanding access 
to microfinance.20 ADB’s improved poverty reduction strategy states that ADB seeks to promote 
sound and efficient financial markets to improve access to finance and achieve pro-poor growth.21 
The project is consistent with ADB’s earlier support to the microfinance sector.22 
 
V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
25.  Category FI (treated as C). In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009), ADB categorizes the investment as FI (treated as C) for impacts on the environment, 
involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples.23 
 
26.  Environmental  and  social  safeguards.  The  loan  will  fund  CFM’s  microfinance 
operations with loans averaging CNY27,080. Most sub-loans will be provided to rural households 
for agribusiness (e.g., livestock, fish, and crop farming); and microenterprises related to trade, 
handicraft making, and services.24 The sub-loans under the ADB loan are expected to have 
minimal environmental, climate change and social impacts. The sub-borrowers’ activities are not 
foreseen to entail land acquisition, physical or economic displacements, or impact on indigenous 
peoples’ communities. CFM will apply the Prohibited Investment Activities List and screening and 
categorization definition of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and comply with relevant 
national laws, standards, and regulations. The project will exclude all sub-loans that exceed 
CNY200,000 and/or those with potential impacts and risks that may be classified as category A 
or B for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. CFM will comply with 
national labor laws and internationally recognized core labor standards in accordance with ADB’s 
Social Protection Strategy. CFM will step up environmental and social performance monitoring 
and reporting to ensure that ineligible sub-borrowers are excluded from ADB financing and that 
robust information on the portfolio’s environmental and social performance is provided to ADB. 
 
27.  Gender equality. The project is classified as effective gender mainstreaming. Following 
ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (1998), CFM has incorporated measures to promote

reduce the gap in access to finance for women by supporting CFM to reach an additional 400,000 
female borrowers and increase its outstanding loan portfolio to female borrowers to CNY19 billion 
by 2024. Key features of the gender action plan include measures directly benefitting women 
farmers  and  microentrepreneurs,  notably  by  increasing  female  borrowers’  skills  to  access 
microloans and staff capacity to respond to female clients. The project will explore the potential 
for new training, such as in digital finance, and expand CFM pilot programs, including nonfinancial 
training.  CFM  will  make  provisions  to  conduct  outreach  campaigns  dedicated  to  women 
microentrepreneurs. Last, the project is expected to help expand CFM employees’ understanding 
of women borrowers’ specific needs. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
28.  CFM was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment documentation includes provisions prohibiting corruption, money laundering, and the 
financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
29.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),25 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of the 
PRC has no objection to the proposed assistance to CFM. ADB will enter into suitable finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
30.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$40,000,000 (or its yuan equivalent) from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to CD Finance 
Management Co., Ltd. for the CD Finance Management Expanding Access to Finance for 
Farmers and Microentrepreneurs Project in the People’s Republic of China, with such terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be 
reported to the Board.
